questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother, concerned about the development of her breasts. On physical examination, the areola is raised above the contour of the breast and forms a secondary mound. According to the Tanner staging system, which stage of breast development is this girl in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stage 4
 

Explanation:

Tanner stages of pubertal development in girls:

BREAST

Stage I (Option A ruled out)

Prepubertal stage, elevation of papilla only

Stage II (Option B ruled out)

Breast buds and papilla slightly elevated, areola begins to enlarge (Median age 9.8 years)

Stage III (Option C ruled out)

Further enlargement of the entire breast tissue

Stage IV

Secondary mound of areola and papilla projecting above the breast tissue (Median age: 12.1 years)

Stage V

Areola recessed to the general contour of the breast (Median age: 14.6 years)

 

PUBIC HAIR

Stage I

No pubic hair present

Stage II

Sparse, long pigmented hair on either side of labia-majora (Median age: 10.5 years)

Stage III

Darker, coarser, and curly hair over the mons pubis

Stage IV

Adult type hair covering the mons only (Median age: 12 years)

Stage V

Adult hair with an inverse triangle distribution (female escutcheon) covering the medial thighs (Median age: 13.7 years)

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with early breast development and pubic hair growth. Laboratory findings reveal elevated gonadotropin levels. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Central precocious puberty

Explanation:

Central precocious puberty is characterized by the early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis, leading to elevated gonadotropin levels (LH and FSH).

Peripheral precocious puberty is due to the production of sex hormones from sources outside the HPG axis, such as the adrenal glands or gonads, without elevated gonadotropin levels (Option B).

 

Premature thelarche refers to isolated early breast development without other signs of puberty before the age of 8 and is typically not associated with elevated gonadotropins (Option C).

 

Premature adrenarche is characterized by early pubic or axillary hair growth due to early adrenal androgen production. It is not typically associated with elevated gonadotropins (Option D).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with early development of facial hair, deepening of the voice, and increased muscle mass. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of androgens, while her estrogen levels remain low. What type of precocious puberty does she most likely have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Heterosexual precocious puberty


 

Explanation:

  • Heterosexual precocious puberty is characterized by the development of secondary sexual characteristics opposite to the child's gender, such as facial hair, deepening of the voice, and increased muscle mass in a girl.
  • Elevated androgen levels with male-pattern characteristics support this diagnosis.

Isosexual/true/complete precocious puberty (Option A) is characterized by early development of secondary sexual characteristics that are appropriate for the child's gender, such as breast development in girls and testicular enlargement in boys. Common causes include:

  • Constitutional – most common
  • Primary hypothyroidism
  • CNS lesions (30%) – trauma, infection (tuberculosis, encephalitis), and some degenerative, neoplastic or congenital defects.

Incomplete precocious puberty (Option C) involves partial development of secondary sexual characteristics without complete progression of puberty.

Premature adrenarche (Option D) involves the early appearance of pubic or axillary hair due to increased adrenal androgen production. Still, it does not typically include the extensive androgenic changes described, such as deepening of the voice and increased muscle mass.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with early breast development and pubic hair growth. Which among the following investigations can differentiate between central and peripheral causes of precocious puberty?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) GnRH stimulation test

Explanation:

The GnRH stimulation test is used to differentiate between central and peripheral causes. 100 µg of GnRH is adminis­tered (SC), and the serum level of LH is measured. A Value Of LH >15 mIU/mL suggests gonadotropin-dependent (central) precocious puberty.

  • In Central Precocious Puberty, GnRH stimulation significantly increases LH and FSH levels, resulting in elevated estrogen levels.
  • In Peripheral Precocious Puberty, these levels will not increase significantly because of negative feedback by the exogenously produced estrogen.

Basic investigations in precocious puberty:

  • Serum hCG, FSH, LH, and prolactin (A baseline prepubertal LH level of greater than 0.3 IU/L is suggestive of Central Precocious Puberty).
  • Thyroid profile (TSH, T4).
  • Serum estradiol, testosterone, 17-OH progesterone, DHEA.
  • USG, CT, or MRI of the abdomen and pelvis to rule out pathology of ovaries, adrenals, or uterus.
  • Skull X-ray, CT scan, or MRI brain—to exclude intracranial lesions (hypothalamic hamartoma).
  • Electroencephalogram (EEG): Abnormal EEG is often associated with CNS disease.
  • X-ray hand and wrist (nondominant) for bone age.
  • GnRH stimulation test

Bone age assessment (Option A): In cases of precocious puberty, bone age is usually advanced beyond the child's chronological age, indicating early hormonal influence on bone growth. However, it does not differentiate between central and peripheral precocious puberty.
 

Pelvic ultrasound (Option B): It can identify ovarian cysts or tumours that might be responsible for peripheral precocious puberty, but it only rules out ovarian pathologies.
 

Serum estradiol levels (Option D): It does not differentiate between central and peripheral causes of precocious puberty.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's delayed onset of puberty. The mother mentions that her daughter has always been underweight and has a very low body fat percentage. On physical examination, the girl shows no signs of breast development or other secondary sexual characteristics.

Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the onset of puberty in females?

choices.text: The onset of puberty occurs early in obese adolescent girls compared to underweight girls.
Estrogen is the most important hormone for the events of puberty, such as breast development and increase in the size of the uterus.
The ratio of the uterine body to the cervix at birth is about 1:2, which becomes 1:1 at menarche.
The sequence of events in puberty starting from early is thelarche, menarche and adrenarche.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The sequence of events in puberty starting from early is thelarche, menarche, and adrenarche.
 

Explanation:
The correct sequence of events in female puberty is typically thelarche (breast development), followed by adrenarche (development of pubic and axillary hair), and lastly, menarche (onset of menstruation).

Obesity is associated with an earlier onset of puberty due to increased estrogen production from adipose tissue (Option A).
 

Estrogen plays a crucial role in the development of secondary sexual characteristics and the growth of the uterus (Option B).
 

The uterine body-to-cervix ratio does change from approximately 1:2 at birth to 1:1 at menarche due to hormonal influences during puberty. It continues through puberty reaching an adult uterine body to cervix ratio of 2:1 (Option C).

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents to the clinic with concerns about not having started her periods and minimal breast development. She has always been shorter than her peers and her weight is at the 10th percentile for her age. She has no chronic illnesses. On physical examination, she has Tanner stage 2 breast development and no pubic hair. Thyroid tests were done, and the levels were normal. Her mother reports a family history of late puberty.

What is the most likely diagnosis according to the criteria for delayed puberty?

choices.text: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Constitutional Delay of Growth and Puberty

Explanation:

  • Constitutional delay of growth and puberty is the most common cause of delayed puberty in adolescents.
  • The girl's consistent growth pattern, family history, and absence of chronic illnesses support this diagnosis.

Delayed Puberty refers to:

  • No periods till 13 years if secondary sexual characters are absent.
  • No periods till 15 years if secondary sexual characters are present.

Causes of Delayed Puberty

Category

Specific Causes

Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
  • Constitutional delay
  • Chronic illness, malnutrition
  • Primary hypothyroidism
  • Isolated gonadotropin deficiency (Kallman’s Syndrome)
  • Intracranial lesions- Tumors (Craniopharyngioma, Pituitary adenomas)

Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (Turner’s Syndrome)
  • Pure gonadal dysgenesis
  • Ovarian failure

Eugonadism
  • Anatomic causes (Mullerian agenesis, Imperforate hymen)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome

 

Gonadal Dysgenesis (Option A) is incorrect because gonadal dysgenesis, such as Turner syndrome, typically presents with additional physical features, such as a webbed neck or shield chest, which are not mentioned in this case.
 

Hyperprolactinemia (Option D) is incorrect because hyperprolactinemia usually presents with galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities, none of which are described in this scenario.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with complaints of severe lower abdominal pain that has occurred cyclically every month for the past six months, but she has never had a menstrual period. She reports no other significant symptoms. On physical examination, her secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed (Tanner stage 4). A pelvic examination reveals a bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, along with the type of amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Imperforate Hymen - Cryptomenorrhea

 

Explanation:

  • Imperforate hymen is a common cause of primary amenorrhea with cyclic abdominal pain. A bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus is a classic sign of this condition, indicating the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen.
  • Cryptomenorrhea is a type of primary amenorrhea in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract (such as Imperforate hymen).

 

Primary Amenorrhea is diagnosed when a young girl who has not yet menstruated by:

  • 13 years (in the absence of secondary sexual characters).
  • 15 years (regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characters).

 

Causes of Primary Amenorrhea

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Primary ovarian failure
  • Resistant ovarian syndrome
  • Galactosemia

Developmental defect of genital tract
  • Müllerian agenesis (2nd most common cause)
  • Imperforate hymen (Cryptomenorrhea) 
  • Vaginal agenesis
  • Transverse vaginal septum 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction
  • Kallmann’s syndrome
  • Craniopharyngioma

Abnormal chromosomal pattern
  • Turner’s syndrome (most common cause)
  • Pure gonadal dysgenesis
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Transverse Vaginal Septum - Primary Amenorrhea (Option A): On examination, the hymen would appear normal because the obstruction is higher up in the vaginal canal, not at the introitus.

 

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) - Primary Amenorrhea (Option C): In AIS, the patient has a 46,XY karyotype and is genetically male but resistant to androgens, leading to female external genitalia. These patients lack a uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina due to normal regression of the Müllerian structures (induced by anti-Müllerian hormone). Therefore, there would be no menstruation and no cyclic abdominal pain. Examination may reveal a short and blind ending vagina.

 

Müllerian Agenesis - Primary Amenorrhea (Option D): In Müllerian agenesis, the patient has a 46,XX karyotype and normal ovarian function, so secondary sexual characteristics develop normally. However, there is an absence of the uterus, upper vagina, and fallopian tubes, so the patient would not experience cyclic abdominal pain as there is no menstruation. The examination would reveal a shortened or absent vagina, not a bluish bulging hymen.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the clinic with concerns about not having started her menstrual periods. The urine pregnancy test was negative & the physical examination showed normal secondary sexual characteristics. Pelvic ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. What is the best investigation in the workup for this patient?

choices.text: Serum FSH , LH , TSH , PRL levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Karyotype analysis
 

Explanation:
In a case where a patient presents with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and an absent uterus on ultrasound, the patient is suspected to have Müllerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, 46, XX) or androgen insensitivity syndrome (46, XY).

Thus, the next appropriate step is to perform a karyotype analysis, which is necessary to differentiate between the two.

Serum FSH, LH, TSH, PRL levels (Option A) is incorrect because these are more helpful in patients without secondary sexual characteristics, where hormonal axis dysfunction is suspected (e.g. hypogonadism, pituitary issues). This patient has normal breast development, indicating intact hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

MRI pelvis (Option C) is incorrect as a first-line investigation. Although MRI is superior to ultrasound in defining pelvic anatomy and confirming absence or presence of uterine remnants, it does not distinguish MRKH from CAIS and is typically reserved for later evaluation.

Examination of vaginal canal (Option D) is incorrect as the best first test. While it can reveal a short or blind vagina, it does not provide definitive diagnostic information, and may be difficult or invasive in adolescents. Moreover, even in expert centres, genetic testing precedes physical exam findings in ambiguous or complex cases.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with monthly cyclic abdominal pain for the past year. She has not yet experienced menarche. The patient appears well-developed for her age, with normal secondary sexual characteristics. External genital examination reveals the following.



An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a distended vagina filled with blood, but the uterus and ovaries appear normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of cyclic abdominal pain, the absence of menarche, and the finding of a bulging, bluish hymen on physical examination are characteristics of an imperforate hymen causing cryptomenorrhea.
  • This condition leads to the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen, which explains the distended vagina observed on ultrasound.

Causes

  • Congenital Causes:
    • Imperforate hymen
    • Transverse vaginal septum
    • Atresia of upper-third of vagina and cervix
  • Acquired Causes:
    • Stenosis of the cervix following amputation, deep cauterization and conization
    • Secondary vaginal atresia following neglected and difficult vaginal delivery.

Clinical Features

  • Patients are usually around 13-15 years old (congenital cases).
  • Symptoms: Periodic lower abdominal pain and, in cases of hematocolpos, urine retention occurs
  • Physical Examination:
    • An abdominal exam reveals a uniform globular mass in the hypogastrium.
    • Vulvar inspection shows a bulging hymen.
    • Rectal examination confirms a full vagina and uterine mass.

 

Management

  • Imperforate Hymen: Perform a cruciate incision and drain the accumulated blood.
  • Cervical Stenosis: Dilate the cervix to relieve the obstruction.

 

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) (Option A): Here an individual with a male karyotype (46, XY) cannot respond to androgens, resulting in female external genitalia despite the presence of testes and the absence of a uterus.
 

MRKH syndrome (Option C): A congenital disorder characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina in females with normal ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics.


Asherman's syndrome (Option D) involves the formation of intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue. This condition can lead to secondary amenorrhea and infertility.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old reports having never had a menstrual period, has a reduced sense of smell, and has been diagnosed with colour blindness. She mentions having a cleft palate repair as a child, and her medical history is significant for unilateral renal agenesis and neurosensory hearing loss. Physical examination reveals an increased arm span relative to her height. Laboratory tests show low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Kallmann syndrome

 

Explanation:

Kallmann syndrome is characterized by delayed puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia), alongside low levels of gonadotropins (LH and FSH). This patient's presentation fits the classic symptoms of Kallmann syndrome, making it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism:
    • Absence of GnRH neurons due to partial or complete agenesis of the olfactory bulb.
    • Results in low levels of gonadotropins (LH and FSH) and sex steroids.
    • Primary amenorrhea in women.
    • Hypogonadism leading to delayed or absent puberty.
    • Absence or reduction of the sense of smell (anosmia) due to olfactory bulb agenesis.
  • Other Associated Features:
    • Color blindness.
    • Cleft palate and possibly cleft lip.
    • Unilateral renal agenesis.
    • Epilepsy.
    • Neurosensory hearing loss.
    • Increased wingspan to height ratio (arm span exceeds height).

Management

  • Induction of Menstruation: Combined estrogen and progestin therapy can induce menstruation in affected women.
  • Induction of Ovulation: Exogenous gonadotropins are used successfully to induce ovulation for fertility purposes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of no menstruation for the past few months. How many months of amenorrhea are required to define this condition as secondary amenorrhea assuming her prior cycles were regular?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3 months

Explanation:

  • Secondary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstrual periods for three consecutive months in a woman who previously had regular menstrual cycles, or for six months in a woman who had irregular cycles.
  • Unlike primary amenorrhea, where menstruation never begins, secondary amenorrhea occurs after a period of normal menstruation.

Common causes of secondary amenorrhea:

  • Pregnancy
  • Chronic illness
  • Hypothyroid/ Pituitary tumors
  • Hyperprolactinemia
  • Empty sella syndrome
  • Thyroid disease
  • PCOS/CAH
  • POI
  • Cushing syndrome

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a complaint of not having had a menstrual period for the past six months. She reports that her menstrual cycles were previously regular, occurring every 28 days. Her medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. A pregnancy test is negative.

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test to evaluate this patient's secondary amenorrhea further?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serum prolactin level

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate initial diagnostic test for evaluating secondary amenorrhea in this patient is serum prolactin level.
  • Elevated prolactin can inhibit gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion, leading to secondary amenorrhea. Since the patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which can also cause elevated prolactin levels, checking serum prolactin is a crucial first step.
  • If prolactin levels are normal, further evaluation with FSH, LH, and estradiol can be considered to assess ovarian function and rule out other endocrine causes. (Options B, C, D).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman reports that her menstrual cycles have become irregular, with a shorter cycle length and variations in flow. She also experiences occasional hot flashes and difficulty sleeping. What is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Perimenopause
 

Explanation:

  • Perimenopause is the period preceding menopause, characterized by hormonal fluctuations and symptoms such as irregular menstrual cycles, hot flashes, and sleep disturbances.
  • Menopause (Option A) is defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation due to the loss of ovarian follicular activity, typically diagnosed retrospectively after 12 consecutive months of amenorrhea. While this patient is experiencing menstrual irregularities, she does not meet the criteria for menopause.
  • Premature (Option B) menopause is defined as menopause occurring at or below the age of 40. Given the patient's age of 46, this diagnosis is not applicable.
  • Late menopause (Option C) occurs when menopause is reached after the age of 55. This patient's age falls within the typical range for menopause, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with complaints of irregular menstrual periods over the past year. She reports experiencing hot flashes, night sweats, and vaginal dryness. Laboratory tests reveal elevated FSH levels. Which of the following hormonal changes best explains the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Decreased inhibin levels
 

Explanation:
Irregular menstrual periods, hot flashes, night sweats, and vaginal dryness are common signs of menopause, caused by declining estrogen levels

  • Decreased inhibin levels (Option A) contribute to the rise in FSH levels during the menopausal transition. Inhibin normally suppresses FSH production, so its decline leads to increased FSH secretion, which is consistent with the patient's elevated FSH levels.
  • Increased LH levels (Option B) also occur during menopause due to decreased estradiol feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. However, LH alone does not directly explain the symptoms described.
  • Declining progesterone levels (Option C) are expected during menopause but are less likely to be the primary cause of the symptoms such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness.
  • Increase in estrogen-to-androgen ratio (Option D) During menopause, ovarian stromal cells increase androgen production due to elevated LH. Although androgen levels rise in ovaries, their peripheral levels reduce due to conversion to estrone in adipose tissue, causing a decreased estrogen-to-androgen ratio. This change results in increased facial hair growth and alterations in voice.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with complaints of frequent severe hot flashes that have increased over the past few months. She has not undergone a hysterectomy. On examination, her vaginal mucosa appears dry. Which of the following is the best management option for her hot flashes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Estrogen-progestin therapy

 

Explanation:

  • Estrogen-progestin therapy is the most effective treatment for managing hot flashes and other menopausal symptoms in women with an intact uterus.
  • Unopposed estrogen therapy can lead to endometrial hyperplasia and an increased risk of endometrial cancer.
  • Estrogen therapy (Option C) alone is preferred in postmenopausal women with a hysterectomy status.
  • Calcium and vitamin D supplementation (Option B) are essential for bone health but do not directly address hot flashes.
  • Low-dose vaginal estrogen (Option A) is effective for treating vaginal dryness and genitourinary symptoms but is less commonly used specifically for managing hot flashes.

Other common symptoms of Menopause:

  • Dyspareunia, dysuria, vaginal dryness, infections, urgency, and incontinence.
  • Thinning, loss of elasticity, and wrinkling of the skin.
  • Increased anxiety, headache, insomnia, irritability, difficulty concentrating, and depression.
  • Loss of bone mass, increasing the risk of osteoporosis and fractures.

Non-Hormonal Therapy for Menopause:

  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) have shown effectiveness in reducing the severity and duration of hot flashes, especially when estrogen therapy is not advisable.
  • Clonidine: This α2 adrenergic agonist can help reduce hot flashes and night sweats.
  • Bazedoxifene: This Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator is often combined with estrogen to manage vasomotor symptoms in women with an intact uterus.
  • Phytoestrogens (isoflavones): Found in foods like soy, phytoestrogens may help lower the incidence of vasomotor symptoms, osteoporosis, and cardiovascular disease.
  • Vitamin E: May provide some relief from hot flashes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of irregular menstrual periods for the past year, along with occasional hot flashes and night sweats but denies any recent pregnancies or use of hormonal contraceptives. Hormonal testing reveals elevated serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and low estradiol levels. Which of the following is false in this condition?

choices.text: Ovarian biopsy is essential to the diagnosis
Due to an accelerated rate of germ cell depletion
Due to the failure of germ cell migration in intrauterine life

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ovarian biopsy is essential to the diagnosis

Explanation:
The condition described is primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), which is characterized by irregular menstrual periods, symptoms of estrogen deficiency (such as hot flashes and night sweats), elevated FSH levels, and low estradiol levels.

  • Primary/Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) is defined as ovarian failure occurring before the age of 40.
  • It occurs due to a failure of germ cell migration (Option D) or an accelerated rate of germ cell depletion during intrauterine life (Option C)This results in few or no follicles left in the ovary by puberty.
  • Ovarian biopsy is not essential to the diagnosis of premature ovarian insufficiency (Option A).

Causes of POI:

  • Genetic: Turner’s syndrome (45, XO), Fragile X syndrome
  • Iatrogenic: Chemotherapy, radiotherapy, ovarian surgery
  • Infectious: Mumps oophoritis, Autoimmune Oophoritis (Option B)
  • Environmental: Smoking, Pesticides
  • FSH receptor abnormalities: Absent or defective FSH receptors, also known as Savage’s syndrome, the clinical features of it includes normal secondary sexual characteristics, regular female karyotype, and usual ovarian reserve, but elevated endogenous gonadotropin levels and low estrogen levels with primary or secondary amenorrhea).
  • Idiopathic

 

Management of POI:

  • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT): To prevent or minimize postmenopausal health risks
  • Corticosteroids: May be helpful in cases of autoimmune disorders
  • Ovulation induction: May be attempted in the presence of follicles using sequential estrogen and progesterone or a GnRH agonist followed by gonadotropins
